DLV
Class ExportDirective

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--DLV.ODBCDirective
        |
        +--DLV.ExportDirective
All Implemented Interfaces:
Directive
public class ExportDirective
extends ODBCDirective

This class represent an ExportDirective.

- #export(databasename,username,password,predname,tablename).
Definition:
Command #export, once computed the first answer set, namely M, for each atom in M having as predicate name predname generates a new tuple. All of the generated tuples are then checked into the table tablename of the database called databasename. 

    Example (3-coloring) The following program is the encoding of the 3-coloring problem: given an undirected graph, represented by facts of the form edge(x , y), assigns to each node one of three colors such that no two adjacent nodes have the same color. Assignments computed in the model(s) of the input program are defined by the predicate "colored".
    
The program shows how to export all the atoms with predicate name "colored" belonging to a stable model, in the relational table named "colors" of the datasource "postgres". Access is granted to the user intrieri with password dlv.

    
 #export(postgres,intrieri,dlv,colored,colors)
 node(X) :- edge(X,Y).
 node(Y) :- edge(X,Y).
 colored(X,red) v colored(X,green) v colored(X,blue)
         :- node(X).
 :- edge(X,Y), colored(X,C), colored(Y,C).
- #export(databasename,username,password,predname,tablename,"REPLACE where *condition*").
Definition:
The second syntactic form of the command #export contains, also, the argument "REPLACE where ". This second form replaces the tuples in the table tablename for which the condition holds. This way it is possible to check some tuples into the table without creating conflicts whenever such tuples violated some integrity constraint of the database (e.g. when the export function introduces the same key value for the key attribute). 

    Example (3-coloring with tuples recovering) The following programs shows the main feature of the second form of the #export command.
    
Given an undirected graph, compute a 3-coloring if the graph. We want to rewrite all of the tuples previously stored in the table colors with the relational predicates colored of a stable model of the program . The datasource is named postgres, access is granted to the user intrieri with password dlv.

 #export(postgres,intrieri,dlv,colored,colors, "REPLACE")
 node(X) :- edge(X,Y).
 node(Y) :- edge(X,Y).
 colored(X,red) v colored(X,green) v colored(X,blue)
        :- node(X).
:- edge(X,Y), colored(X,C), colored(Y,C).

Note - The argument "REPLACE" without any specification, causes the elimination of the all tuples in the table tablename. Whenever a partial updating is necessary, it is possible to specify the condition "REPLACE where" followed by a condition , which deletes the tuples for which the condition holds.

Version:
2.0
Author:
Francesco Ricca
